• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Repeat violations
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each

• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10177 Resident Restraint
Section (1) The facility shall establish and follow written policy and
Description procedures specifying the use of resident restraint.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On June 1, 2023, Youth A assaulted another youth in the center.
Staff 1 had to restrain Youth A. Youth A reported today on June
6th, 2023, that "Staff 1 choked me and dragged me across the
room". Youth A reported that he had a bruise on the right side of
his neck. Youth A was observed today with no bruise. Staff 1 did
an incident report on the incident.
Investigation Administrator 1/Complainant was interviewed face-to-face at
the facility, on 6/8/2023. He had no further information to provide
but reported Youth A is still lodged in the facility and is being kept
away from the youth he assaulted.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility, on
6/8/2023. He reported hitting another youth before Staff 1 pushed
him off the other youth. Staff 1 jumped on top of him pushing him
to the floor. Staff 1 is reported to have placed her arm around his
neck and drag him for approximately 8 to 10 feet across the floor.
He reported she was the only staff present and never said
anything to him while taking these actions. Other staff showed up
approximately 15 seconds later and Staff 1 still had her arm
around his neck. When the other staff tried to get him in his room,
Staff 1 released him, and the other staff started telling him to calm
2

down. He denied resisting the restraint until they started putting
him into his room. Once in his room doorway, Youth A reported he
just went into his room. He denied saying anything to staff during
the incident. He reported he feels safe in the facility and that staff
are always observing the youth. He reported being “treated alright”
in the facility.
Youth B was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B was in the pod
and reported asking Youth A if he was “good” to which Youth A
told him to “shut up”. Youth A was sitting on a chair across the
room from Youth A when Youth A got up, walked towards Youth
B, took his shirt off, and began to punch Youth B. Youth B put his
hands above his head to protect himself before heading to his
room. He was again attacked by Youth A before dropping to the
floor and waiting for staff to open his room door. He observed
Staff 1 pinning Youth A to the ground. He reported hearing Youth
A say staff grabbed him by the neck. Youth B reported being
examined by the nurse following the incident. Youth B reported
not feeling safe at the facility because other youth are targeting
him, and he doesn’t believe staff are doing anything to stop this
targeting. He described the targeting when he hears another youth
point at his room and say, “let me know when you want me to
greenlight it”.
Youth C was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported being present
during the altercation between Youth A and Youth B. He reported
Youth A was mad at Youth B because Youth A claimed Youth B
hit him twice during a basketball game two days prior. He
described the incident. Youth A took off his shirt and began to hit
Youth B. Youth A had been acting “weird” by all his pacing while in
the pod. Staff 1 tried to restrain Youth A after he hit Youth B and it
didn’t seem like she was successful. Staff 1 tackled Youth A after
running him down. She had her arms around him (standing at the
time), and Youth A fell over as she grabbed him. Staff 1 had one
arm under Youth A’s arm pit and one over his other shoulder with
her hand on his chest. He was unable to recall anything else since
he went to his room. Youth C feels safe at the facility and believes
staff are doing their jobs well.
Youth D was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported being in the
pod at the time and gave the following information. Youth A took
off his shirt and fought Youth B. Prior to this Youth A was walking
around the pod. Staff 1 grabbed Youth A to keep him from
3

fighting. Staff 1 was on the ground and Youth A fell to the ground,
but “I didn’t see how it happened”. Staff 1 was on her hands and
knees. Youth D was in his room and had a limited view of the
incident. He reported Youth A claimed staff grabbed him by his
neck. Youth D reported feeling safe at the facility and all of the
restraints he has observed appear appropriate.
Staff 1 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported Youth A was
pacing around the pod and she told him to stop. Youth A then sat
down and he responded with “yo bro stop talking to me”. After
sitting down for a moment, Youth A said he was going to get some
water. He then took off his shirt and began attacking Youth B.
Staff 1 observed Youth A landing two to three hits on Youth B.
She had to call for help before assisting Youth B. Staff 1
requested a “lockdown” then grabbed Youth A and “tried to drag
him to his room”. She grabbed Youth A by his waist and one of his
arms at first. She did not recall having one of her arms around his
neck nor being on the floor, but she believed Youth A was on the
floor at some point. After viewing the video recording, Staff 1
asked why other staff in the room did not intervene and help her.
She reported it is hard to perform CPI when your only one person.
She believed the other staff in the room should have become
involved by taking Youth A’s other arm. She reported not trying to
get near Youth A’s neck, but he was resisting her during the
restraint. After she dragged him to the other side of the pod, Staff
3 became engaged and held Youth A against the wall. She
recalled being asked to leave the area at this time by Supervisor.
She reported this was her first restraint although she had witness
other restraints. She was aware of the other youth teasing Youth
B because “he put his personal business out there by telling the
other youth he had performed oral sex on an older male for money
and alcohol”.
Staff 2 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported receiving a call
for help and leaving his pod to assist. When he arrived, Youth A
was already in his room and two staff were standing near him in
the room. He reported speaking to Youth A four to five days later
and Youth A told him Youth B elbowed him in the mouth playing
basketball and hit in him the mouth with his shoulder the day after.
Youth A informed him he was ignoring Youth B until Youth B
called him a “crackhead” in line earlier in the day of the incident.
He had no firsthand information on the restraint but did report
knowing of the term “greenlighting’, and suggested it means
someone is going to be the target of attack at any time. He
4

reported understanding Youth B has shared things about himself
that will cause him to be picked on. Staff do their best to protect
Youth B by paying attention to other youth around him. These
issues are sexual in nature. Staff 2 reported there was an informal
debriefing after the incident, and he learned very little about the
incident other than Staff 1 got hurt during the restraint. He
reported CPI is “team based” and should not be conducted by one
person.
Staff 3 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported observing Youth
A attacking Youth B from another pod and quickly went to the
location of the fight. He observed Staff 1 falling on top of Youth A
but believed it was an accident. Youth A was laying on his side
and she was over him. He believed Youth A slipped trying to get
to Youth B again but not sure of this assessment. Staff 3 reported
stopping when he entered the room because he wanted to assess
the situation before engaging. His rational for not engaging when
first observing the situation was because he “needed to think
before reacting because something could go wrong”. He reported
Staff 1 then grabbed Youth A to stop him from getting to Youth B
and she had her right arm around his right shoulder. She was not
choking him but as they moved across the room her left arm
moved up his chest and her arm contacted Youth A’s neck. Staff 3
did not believe Staff 1 was “dragging him to harm him” and Staff 1
made the “wrong move by dragging him”. He reported taking over
when Staff 1 reached the other side of the pod with Staff 5, and
Staff 4 assisting him. He reported other youth tease Youth B
because of his personal life he shared with them, and staff are
always alert to interactions between Youth B and others. He
denied knowing what “greenlighting” means.
Staff 4 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported receiving a
radio call for help and went to pod D. When she reached the pod,
she observed Youth B standing in front of his door, so she let him
into his room. Staff 1 and Youth A were on the floor. Rather than
engaging in the restraint right away, she “took a second to see
what was going on”. Staff 4 didn’t see how Staff 1 moved Youth A
to the far wall in the pod, but she remembers once there, she
grabbed one arm of Youth A and used the wall for support. She
didn’t want Youth A dropping to the floor because not only would
Youth A go to the floor, but staff engaged would go to the floor.
She recalled Staff 3 was supporting Youth A from in front of him
as they escorted him to his room. Staff 4 reported Staff 3, Staff 5
and herself, who entered the pod should have reacted quicker and
5

not paused as they did. She knew that “greenlighting” means that
someone is about to attack someone. She reported Youth B
brought the issue of Youth E saying greenlighting to staff attention
but is unsure if this was placed in the shift log. She reported both
Youth E and Youth B were placed in their rooms for the
“greenlighting incident”. She acknowledged staff are to pay close
attention to Youth B because of other youth responding to some of
his behaviors.
Staff 5 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported receiving a
radio call for help. When entering the pod, she paused and
scanned the room “for a second”. She felt timid because she just
came back to work a short time ago. She observed Staff 1 over
Youth A and Youth A on his knees. Staff 1 had an arm over the
top of his shoulder and the other arm was higher up on the
shoulder near the neck area. She didn’t see Staff 1’s arm choking
Youth A and she didn’t see Staff 1 drag Youth A across the room.
Once she observed the video recording, she recalled the dragging
actions and reported it never should have happened. She reported
if a youth is on the floor, Staff should not have tried to move him
and waited for help before attempting a restraint or to move him to
a standing position. There were enough staff present to do an
appropriate restraint of Youth A. Staff 5 did engage in the restraint
when Staff 3 and Staff 4 had him against the wall before escorting
Youth A to his room. She had heard the term “greenlighting” a few
times in the facility and knew of the incident between Youth E and
Youth B. She reported Youth E was not upset when he said it and
both youths received a consequence for their inappropriate
interaction. She reported Youth B created the situation when he
“talks about inappropriate things and then asks staff what they are
going to do about it”.
Trainer was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported having
reviewed the video recording and being the primary CPI trainer for
the facility. He reported CPI doesn’t do a lot for engagement and
getting a hold on a youth is difficult. Initially staff does what they
need to do to get a hold on the youth but must be very careful
because grabbing a youth can cause an injury. Trainer reported
staff should not engage without assistance. Observing the video
recording, Trainer had no issue with the initial hold by Staff 1
when she had an arm over his shoulder and the other arm near
his chest. He reported Staff 1’s arm should not be near Youth A’s
chest. He identified the first problem is other staff showing up and
Staff 1 continued on her own without assistance. However, he
6

reported it is not wrong for the other staff to pause. He reported
Staff 1 dragging Youth A across the room is not something that is
trained in CPI. Staff are not to carry a youth and if moving
someone staff should encourage and “can use their hip to move
them forward”. He reported training staff to stop and step in if
another staff is doing something wrong and Staff 3 and Staff 4
should have moved into a CPI hold to move Youth A. He reported
because of policy changes, all video recordings of restraints are
reviewed.
Supervisor was interviewed via Video Conference, on
6/14/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
working in “control” when the incident occurred. He heard the
radio call and began opening youth’s room doors on the pod. This
allowed the youth to go to their rooms as required during a
“lockdown”. When he observed the pod over the video system, he
noticed Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 restraining Youth A against the
wall and Youth A calmed down. He did not observe the restraint
when Staff 1 was engaged with Youth A. He reported being aware
of the tenson between Youth A and Youth B which spilled over
from a basketball game in the gym a day before. He checked on
both Youth A and Youth B the next day to ensure they were doing
well medically. The only medical issue needs were Youth A’s
swollen knuckles.
Staff 6 was interviewed via phone, on 7/7/2023. She reported
observing Staff 1 having her arms wrapped about Youth A upon
entering the pod. She doesn’t remember if she observed Staff 1
drag Youth A across the room. She did remember Staff 3, Staff 4,
and Staff 5 engaging with Youth A against the far wall from the
entrance door. She reported this was her first involvement in a
restraint since beginning her employment two months ago.
Documents Reviewed:
Circuit court General Profile Report for Youth A. There is no
date on this document. Youth A’s demographic information,
admission information and offenses are listed.
20th Circuit court/Ottawa County Juvenile Detention Resident
Grievance Form dated 6/3/23. This form was completed and
signed by Youth A. It is documented, “when restraining me, staff
put me in a chokehold and dragged me across the room by my
neck”. He documents having a bruise on his neck.
7

Incident report number 330595 dated 6/1/23 regarding Youth
A. This incident is described as “Assault & Battery” and lists staff
witnesses as Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, Staff 6 and
youth witnesses as Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E. Two other
youth are identified but no longer in the program or facility. The
summary section of this document outlines each staff present and
having knowledge of the incident.
• Supervisor documented the following information. Staff 3
standing outside of the pod observed Youth A punch Youth
B 3-4 times while Youth B was in a kneeling position. Staff
1 swiftly secured Youth A’s arm and waist while attempting
to pull him away from Youth B. Staff 3, Staff 4, Staff 5, and
Staff 6 entered and engaged in restraining Youth A. Staff 4
and Staff 5 secured his arms, Staff 6 secured his left leg
and Staff 3 secured his waist and shoulders. Youth A was
strongly resisting the restraint. Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5
escorted Youth A to his room where he stopped resisting.
• Staff 4 documented the following about the incident. Staff 1
called a lockdown over the radio, and I responded quickly.
Staff 1 was securing Youth A on the floor while Staff 4 went
to open Youth B’s door to his room. Then Staff 4 went to
help Staff 1 and Staff 3 with the restraint of Youth A. Both
staff were using the CPI techniques for the restraint. Staff 4
switched with Staff 1 and secured Youth A’s right arm, Staff
5 secured Youth A left arm and Staff 3 was in front of Youth
A securing his shoulders. They then escorted Youth A to
his room.
• Staff 1 documented the following. She called a lockdown
and responded quickly securing Youth A on the floor. The
rest of her documentation reads exactly the same as Staff
4’s documentation.
• Staff 3 documented the following about the incident. Staff 1
called a lockdown and Staff 3 noticed a youth was being
assaulted by Youth A. Upon entering the pod, Staff 3
noticed Staff 1 secured Youth A from the back as Staff 3,
Staff 4, and Staff 5 secured his front, back and shoulders.
Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 escorted Youth A to his room.
• Staff 6 documented the following. Staff 1 called a lockdown
over the radio and Staff 6 ran straight to the pod. Upon
entering the pod, she noticed Staff 1 secured Youth A
around the chest. Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 all ran and
helped with the restraint.
8

• Staff 5 documented the following about the incident. She
responded to a radio call and when entering observed Staff
1 on the floor with Youth A. Staff 4 secured his right arm
and Staff 5 secured his left arm. Staff 3 secured his
shoulder from the front. They struggled around the round
table because he was resisting, and they escorted him to
his room. Youth A calmed down once in his room.
• It is documented on this form that Trainer has identified CPI
training needs and refresher training is in the process of
being scheduled.
20th Circuit Court – Juvenile court Policy/Procedure
Memorandum Use of force and De-escalation Interventions
1.37 dated April 2023. This document outlines the appropriate
use of Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) techniques for physical
restraints. Detention staff are required to complete initial CPI
training prior to working with any youth and annual CPI refresher
training thereafter. Medical services are to be notified of any injury
to a youth and seen immediately and if not be added to the
medical list to be seen by the nurse at the next available time.
20th Circuit Court/Juvenile Detention Preliminary Resident
Plan for Youth A and dated 4/26/2023. This document outlines
specific issues that maybe present with Youth A at the time of his
admission to the facility. He is not taking any prescription
medication and the specific services he is to receive are listed as
food, safety and security, shelter, and clothing. Other services to
be provided include medical, education, church, and CMH.
20th Circuit Court/Juvenile Detention Resident Service Plan
for Youth A and without a date. This document is identified as
the 30-day report. This document identifies Youth A is staying in
detention until his next designation hearing on 6/19/23. There are
no plans for another placement because he must go through his
designation process first.
20th Circuit Court/Juvenile Detention Resident Service Plan
for Youth A and without a date. This document is identified as
the 15-report. This document identifies Youth A will be staying in
detention until the designation hearing on 6/19/23 and there are
no plans for another placement.
Medical Sick Calls dated 6/2/2023 09:50 with RN (Task
Priority: 1). This document is for Youth A. X-ray 2 – view, right
hand to r/o fracture of 5th digit per doctor. Subjective: please
reassess patient was involved in a fight with another patient, and
9

he used his right hand to strike the other patient and complains
that his pinky finger on his right hand is broken. He can bend his
fingers. His knuckles on his right hand appear swollen and
requested he be given ice for the swelling tonight.
Incident report medical log for Youth A dated 6/1/2023. This
document provided a summary per the nurse. Youth A may be
given ice for his swollen hand L/A TFN.
Law Enforcement report #1384 on 6/1/2023 #23-06010214
Assault and Battery. This document outlines the interviews
conducted by Law Enforcement at the facility on 6/1/23. Staff 1
was interviewed and reported she got Youth A into a hold to
prevent him from assaulting anyone else and called for backup.
Ottawa County Sheriff’s Office 23-06070085 Supp2 Report
#915. This document outlines the interview of Youth A by Law
Enforcement and MDHHS worker. Youth A reported Staff 1 used a
choke hold to drag him across the room and that it left a bruise on
his neck. He reported Staff 1’s right arm was over his right
shoulder and bruised the right side of his neck. He pointed to a
spot on his neck and Law Enforcement observed “a small freckle”.
Law Enforcement did not observe a bruise and Youth A admitted
the bruise went away. Law Enforcement noted after watching the
video recording that Staff 1’s right arm was never over Youth A’s
right shoulder because it was under Youth A’s right armpit. Law
Enforcement found Youth A’s claim to be unfounded and the case
is closed.
Youth A Progress notes covering the period 5/29/23 2:07 PM
to 6/1/23 3:00 PM. It is document on 5/31/23 at 9:31 PM Youth A
and Youth B “were playing basketball when he became
aggressive. Both Youth A and Youth B are documented as
“posturing up to each other” causing them to be placed in their
rooms for the rest of the night.
CPI Situational Application: Principles of Holding – Standing
position. This document has three diagrams showing the “Lower-
level Holding, Medium-Level Holding, and Higher-Level Holding”.
The Lower-Level Holding diagram shows staff standing to the left
side and slightly behind the youth. Staff’s left arm is holding the
youth’s left arm at the elbow and his right hand is holding the right
elbow of the youth. Staff’s right leg is next and touching the
youth’s left leg from the hip to the floor. The Medium-Level holding
position has two staff standing on either side and slightly behind
the youth. The staff have a hold on the youth’s arm just below the
10

elbow and near the wrist. Staff have their leg closest to the youth
touching the hip of the youth and ending with their feet touching.
The Higher-Level holding position has two staff standing to the
sides and slightly behind the youth. The staff are holding the youth
just above the elbow with their hands locked. Their hips are
touching the youth’s hips and their foot closes to the youth are
touching the youth’s feet.
Human Resources file for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 has no
documented disciplinary action in her HR file. She completed her
orientation on 3/23/23 and CPI-Nonviolent Crisis intervention
training on 5/15/23.
Video Recording Review. The recording opens with a bird’s eye
view of the pod where the incident took place. Youth A is sitting at
a table across the room by himself. Youth B is sitting at a table by
himself to the right of Staff 1 and across the room from Youth A.
Staff 1 is sitting with her back to the wall and at a table with three
youth. To her left is another youth sitting at a table by himself. 20-
seconds into the video, Youth A stands and begins to walk in the
general direction of Youth B. When getting close to Youth B,
Youth A takes off his shirt, yells “bitch” and rushes to Youth B
where he begins to punch him. Staff 1 stands and makes a radio
call before rushing after Youth A. During the time of Staff 1 making
the radio call, Youth B gets away from Youth A and begins to run
across the room. Youth A is closely following and punching at
Youth B the whole time. The other youth in the room move
towards their bedrooms and away from the action. At the 33-
second mark, Staff 1 has caught up to Youth A who is standing
over Youth B, punching him. Staff 1 grabs Youth A from behind
and both go to the floor with Youth A in a prone position and Staff
1 on top of him. Staff 3 enters the room and stands in the
doorway. Staff 1 attempts to pick Youth A up by putting her right
arm under Youth A’s right arm and grabbing his arm near his
armpit. Her left arm is on Youth A’s chest, and she drags Youth A
several feet across the room. As she repositions her hold her left
arm draws closer to Youth A’s neck area. As she reaches the far
wall, Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 engage with Youth A placing his
arms around Youth A from his front. Staff 4 enters and moves to
hold Youth A by his right arm. At this time Staff 1 moves away and
stands in the middle of the room. Staff 5 enters the room and
grabs Youth A by the left arm/shoulder. At 1:28 mark Staff 1
leaves the area as Staff 3, Staff 4, and Staff 5 are overheard trying
to deescalate Youth A. At 2:10 mark staff move Youth A who has
begun to resist more into his room. Staff 2 enters the pod and
goes directly into Youth A’s room.
11

Analysis Based upon interviews, written documentation, and video
recordings evidence supports Staff 1 did not follow the facility
approved restraint techniques. Staff 1’s dragging Youth A across
the room is not an approved method nor her arm placement on
Youth A’s neck.
Technical Assistance:
It was recommended the facility ensure the initial CPI action to
take when a need to physically manage a youth is understood by
staff to prevent a delay in response when youth or staff are
struggling in a restraint.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established
SIR 2023C0000175 Dated 2/23/23; CAP approval 3/27/2023.
SIR 2023C0000308 dated 4/3/2023; CAP approved 4/18/2023.
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10107 Employment policies and procedures.
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written employment policies
Description and procedures that shall assure that staff are emotionally stable
and of suitable health, ability, experience, and education to
perform the duties assigned.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation During this investigation it was discovered Staff 1 did not follow
the procedure of checking written documentation when coming on
shift.
Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported no one
informed her of any tenson between Youth A and Youth B so she
was unaware of issues between them.
Staff 2 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported information
about the youth’s behaviors should be documented in log notes
and information is passed in “control”.
Staff 4 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported knowing that
Youth A and Youth B were had tenson between them and was
unsure if Staff 1 knew this information. She knew this information
from shift change meeting throughout the week. She was unsure if
this information was in the shift log but reported it should have
been. She reported, if tenson exists between youth, it should be
written down on the behavior change sheet and reflection sheet.
Staff 5 was interviewed via Video Conference, on 6/14/2023 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported information is
12

passed between shifts through a pod summary in the pod binder
at the end of the shift. At the end of the night staff are required to
write summaries. She believes staff should look at the binder to
gather information but is unsure if this action is required.
Supervisor was interviewed via Video Conference, on
6/14/2023 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. In regard to
information being passed in the facility, he reported supervisors
will talk and share information and progress notes are completed
electronically. A shift summary is kept in each pod and one in the
control area. He reported there are shift meeting where all
available staff are to attend, and issues are discussed. He was not
sure about a policy for reading the summary before beginning a
shift.
Documents Reviewed:
Program – Detention Resident Behavior Management –
General Procedures 12.1 dated 5/17/23. This document outlines
different procedures for the staff to follow at the facility. Under the
section titled “Daily Activity Log” it states, “Staff are required to
review the logged activity since their last shift either from a
computer terminal or from the paper copy.” Information to be
logged is outlined and includes incidents and youth confinement.
Another section is titled “Shift Change/Program Management and
outlines staff’s responsibilities when coming or leaving a shift.
“Oncoming staff shall be briefed from previous shift staff as to the
overall cooperation for the youth, behavior problems, medical
concerns, staff alerts, and other pertinent issues at a shift change
meeting.” There are several other duties listed in the section of the
